disposed in a mode not altogether dissimilar, <s>in form</s> whilst the constitution of their soft
bodies is essentially the same. And a remarkable connecting link between Orbitolite
and Sponges, seems to be presented to us in the curious <u>Thalassicolla</u>
discovered by M Huxley [Annals of Natural History 2nd Series
vol viii, p. 433]. The relations of Orbitolite to other Foraminifera
have already been partly touched-on, and will become more
clear hereafter, when the types which most approximate to it
shall have been themselves described.

VI <u>Of the Species Orbitolites</u>
68  It only remains to enquire, whether the diversities which
have been described as existing among Orbitolites afford any
ground for assuming the existence of more than a single species.
With regard to the <u>recent</u> forms, with which, so far as they are
at present known, I have made myself fully acquainted, I can
speak confidently; since, as I have demonstrated, the Orbitolite
with a <u>single</u> stratum of cells (<u>O. marginalis</u> of Lamarck,<u>Porites</u>
of Ehrenberg), that with a <u>double</u> stratum (<u>Amphisorus</u> of
Ehrenberg) and that with <u>multiple</u> strata (<u>Marginopora</u> of
Quoy & Gaimard, <s>Orbitolites complanata of Lamarck,</s> <u>Orbiculina Tonga</u> of Prof. Williamson) are
